author: {'steamid': '76561198210792775', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1707877076}
review:
Not a really fun game. It's buggy and I lost all of my progress because I decided to posses the cat to go the meeting on the second floor. Shame on the dev for not fixing the bugs and releasing this game as it is. 

I'll admit the writing is excellent in some places with the stock characters. Pity that the bugs ruined my progress. 

If you're looking for a visual novel though if you're willing to overlook the bugs then you found it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198987321899', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1706379748}
review: Jogão, fiquei envolvido com a história do começo ao fim. A soundtrack, ambientação e os diálogos são muito bem feitos. Cada personagem é único e com histórias muito interessantes. Passei um ótimo tempo tentando solucionar o mistério :D

author: {'steamid': '76561199083307450', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1706128437}
review:
(think I fell asleep with this on once - playing time is a little inflated prob more like 4-5 hours)

Will start out by saying - I don't really think this is my cup of tea. I spent more time frustrated than having fun, but I still want to leave a positive review here because perhaps someone else who doesn't have the same gaming quirks I do will find some enjoyment in it. Most of the game is really well done.

Great concept. The art is great, the faux-retro pixel art style popular with a lot of indie titles. The music is in the same style, nice and crunchy, different characters have different themes which is cool. The Ship has a lot of character, and the actual characters are all well designed and distinct. Their personal stories vary in quality (none are bad per se, some just really cliche) but the good ones are good. The mystery itself is intriguing. 

Now here's where it started being more frustrating than fun to me, and where other's opinions may differ. The actual gameplay is straight out of 90s adventure games in the sense that you have to rub everything on everything, but in this sense rubbing everything on everything is just talking to people over and over with different people until you finally find a fresh, precious morsel of new dialogue. The perceptive shifts sound cool until you realize instead of exhausting all dialogue options with a character and then moving on to the next, you now have to do that with every character you can possibly control. Then later you unlock full possessions which just means you now have a whole new thing to rub on everything. Most of your time will be spent wondering around the ship as different characters, trying to figure out just who in the hell you're supposed to talk to to trigger progression. It's not so bad early, when your possessions are limited, but by Chapter 4 it just becomes a mess of guess work and walking.

Speaking of walking, most of the characters are painfully slow. No sprint. Your ghost form is way faster than anything else, but characters hang out in specific locations, meaning most of the time to interact with a character as a character, you have some walking to do. One character goes faster with his ability, but it's drugs so it makes your screen all fuzzy and annoying to look at. 

Which segways me into the abilities, which I feel are wasted potential. Other than one allowing you to sequence break (Gwen's peeking ability unlocks the room for you as a ghost, allowing you to enter rooms a chapter early) they're all fairly useless or have very specific uses. 

Finally, the ending is such "you have to do these specific things in this specific order" 90s adventure game bull shit I was pulling my hair out. I don't care, I used a guide. You will too, because the entire game trains you to exhaust every dialogue option, but now, at the very end, the solution is to use specific dialogue in a specific order with specific characters, AFTER making sure you get the easily missable dialogue that could make it impossible to get the good ending. It's so 90s it hurts.

Ultimately, that's why this review is a recommend. If you love 90s adventure game bullshit minus moon logic but with an extra heaping of rub everything on everything followed by a side of "do this specific thing in this specific order or else. and better make sure you found all the missable stuff!" then you will probably love this. I hate that kind of thing, so the back half of the game became a slog to me. The mystery was interesting enough that I wanted to see what happened, and the art and music was good, so I powered through, but I was very close to quitting at points. 

Also, save often, characters can become stuck and you can fly out of the map.

author: {'steamid': '76561198351401498', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1693719045}
review: A fascinating gameplay loop with hints of narrative brilliance, although somewhat marred by a lackluster ending which felt vaguely insensitive to some of the themes discussed. I recommend playing if you're a game developer looking for inspiration, or are just generally interested in shorter indie games with unique mechanics, but I wouldn't consider this a "must-play" either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981470163', 'num_games_owned': 1091, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1459004473}
review:
I played this many years ago, and many years ago I found the 1 man developer blog and his reflections (and frustrations) on (IIRC, the lack of success vs how much effort it took) on this game.

It is a tragedy, as this is a good Earthbound-inspired RPG that has more depth and character then games with million+ dollar budgets and 100s of people working on it. 

Video games will survive and go forward as a medium with people who have a vision and passion for their project like this irrespective of money/resources, not the soulless corpos who are doing a pretty good job dragging it into the mud more and more every year. 

One needs to be disparaged and the other elevated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996859750', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 397, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1693094001}
review: Incredibly intriguing adventure where you are a ghost trying to figure out how you died in a ship. This is superbly written, with lots of rich dialogue. It was fascinating how the twists and turns of the plot turn this story into something really grim and dark. If you like narrative games, you can't go wrong with this gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156701926', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1498294725}
review:
The game was fun. But, there was way too much walking back and forth and speaking to the same characters over and over... and over, and over again... to "unlock" everything and completely clear the game, tbh. It got tiresome and a bit tedious. Also the "tie-ins to the original flash game" served only one purpose: to inform me there was such a thing. Shouldn't have been achievements, especially two separate ones, if the game wasn't going to make anything of it imo...

But, that's a self-imposed annoyance after all, so I can't hold it against the game. The story was fun, and took surprising turns. i actually enjoyed piecing together the mysteries of what happened, I do recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198264720318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1619314723}
review: The mystery behind it is wonderful, and the game is tons of fun! My only issue is that I encountered a number of bugs to the point I had to restart twice! Still, I'd recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137879086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1680155746}
review:
This game went well above my expectations- it has a charming style which serves a fun plot and likable characters. I enjoyed the writing, it was a good balance of humorous and intense. This is a murder mystery game, so much of the game-play consists of talking to people and confirming facts, but each character has an interesting mechanic of their own that makes the process more dynamic. Like all entries in the murder mystery genre, I had a much better time playing with friends than on my own. 

The puzzles (term used loosely) were not unreasonable, and the in-game hint system was helpful. We never needed a guide, thankfully, though there was a good bit of trial and error. Nothing egregious though. My one issue: The stairs on the ship can be quite buggy if you step onto them wrong- I did get stuck on them after the transition screen a few times. Since this game doesn't autosave, it was a bit of a pain, so I would suggest saving often to avoid any backtracking.

author: {'steamid': '76561199446895073', 'num_games_owned': 40, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1679852083}
review: This game! where do I even start. This game is a wonderful mystery story full of twists and turning perspectives, literally! I adore this game's bottle setting, learning about everyone on this mysterous boat with you while finding out more about your identity in the process.The game has a very light-hearted Mother-esc sense of humor but is serious when it needs to be creating a perfect balance and that tone really brings you close to the cast of quirky characters around you.I highly recommend this game to Mother 3 fans specifically due to the constantly changing central location, tone, and music even this game offers.If you play this game, make sure to go in blind for the best experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198121292584', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1531347015}
review: One of my all time favorite games. The plot, the characters, the music, the ambiance. All of it is so full of emotion and mystery behind every moment. If you have the time to try it out and enjoy murder mysteries, I 100% recommend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024614400', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1678346832}
review: Fun if you like murder mysteries and detective work. There's a couple glitches with movement and NPC pathing can be frustrating (they can block doorways or box you in). Saving is also annoying because, when you unpossess certain characters, they tend to run away to their usual path by the time you've finished saving. Game can definitely benefit from certain quality of life changes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274206484', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1673406634}
review:
Really interesting mystery game, every character including the main character was really well-written, twists upon twists, it goes places I wouldn't have expected.

A couple of bugs, like some text lines being white or grey when they shouldn't, but overall quite polished.

There are some quite dark themes without it being gratuitous.

If you make another game in this series, I would recommend the 'full control' mode to be an expansion of the regular dialogue trees rather than a separate set of dialogue options that you can use while controlling anyone. It was quite strange to see X character ask if they though X was guilty, for example.

Also, even if you can only uncover the mystery using your ghost powers, it'd be nice if you didn't have to use direct possession to incriminate and catch someone. It just feels like a bit of a cop out.

Score: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993419334', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1671016470}
review:
The mystery genre is a strange one when it comes to games. It is at the same time a common genre and yet one that doesn't seem to have very many good examples to pull from. Most simply have you follow a red line through the aesthetics of a mystery, without much input from the player themself. Well, I'm happy to say that Why Am I Dead At Sea (quite a mouthful of a title) is not one of those games. Here we have instead a great example of how to do mystery right – with depth, maturity, creativity and a crew full of ogres.

With ogres I of course mean the Shrek kind, because these characters sure have layers. You are a ghost looking to solve your own murder, and the main way you do this is by possessing the people on the ship. You do so by getting to know them, as the game puts it, which might lead you to believe that you know everything there is to know about them. What is great is that you won’t. Seeing into their thoughts, snooping through their room and even walking about in their skin is just not enough, because there can still be a surprise that you didn’t see coming, a secret they hid from you. This game really understands that in order to make a mystery game interesting, the characters can’t just lie to each other, they have to lie to the player as well.

On top of that, there is just a lot of details put into the cast. Every character has their own text scroll “voice”, their own music and their own thoughts and skills. They even walk differently, with some characters walking faster or slower than others, and they move around the ship in a way that makes sense for them and the story at large. All of them have different ways of doing things and they’re all useful in solving the problems the game throws at you. That’s not even mentioning that they all have their personal stories to share, all with set up and great pay off. All of this makes these characters more than just colourful, more than just charismatic and quirky; it makes them feel like people. It’s simply great.

There are more positives I can list, from dialogue to plot structure to the resolution of it all, but I’m afraid I’ll spoil the experience of getting surprised throughout the game. Instead, I will mention a couple of flaws. One, the movement is a bit clunky, especially in your spirit form. It’s not a big problem, but it can feel a bit irritating when you’re chasing someone that you want to talk to or possess. Two, there are bugs in this game, mainly one I had the misfortune to run into twice where I got stuck in a wall when climbing the stairs, soft-locking the game and requiring a restart. Save your game, and do it often! I learned this the hard way, having to replay some sections because of the bug.

Overall though, Why Am I Dead At Sea is a great mystery game, requiring you to actually solve the riddles with only limited guidance and the possibility of failure to keep you on your toes. It deserves more attention than it has gotten and should be what other games in the genre aspire to be. Play it. You won’t regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028090178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1667454961}

author: {'steamid': '76561198119884379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1665507837}
review:
Why Am I Dead at Sea puts a very interesting spin on the murder mystery genre that blows the quintessential body drop clear out of the water! You are the body! More to the point, you’re the soul that has left the body that is presumably dead, and it’s your soul mission (see what I did there?!) to figure out who dunnit!

The gameplay is pretty straightforward. You play as Smilla, the spirit of the dead captain, and influence the thoughts and actions of the other people aboard the ship in order to uncover the gruesome truth behind your apparent murder. To accomplish this, you can possess the passengers and crew members and steer conversations and search for clues. Now, Why Am I Dead at Sea is actually a spiritual successor (I really should stop, but I won’t!) to the devs’ original flash game simply called Why Am I Dead. This is relevant because there are some major quality of life improvements to the possession mechanic. For starters, you can’t just go hopping into anyone’s body all willy-nilly, ya silly-billy! No, you must unlock the ability to do so by learning vulnerable secrets about the rest of the cast of characters in order initially to gain limited control over them and eventually total control. You must have the characters interact with one another, as well as the environment in order to accomplish this. 

Seems like a perfect recipe for f<3<3<3 around and find out, don’t it? On the contrary! To help guide you, you have a spiritually prescient kid named Paulo who has locked himself in his room and can only be interacted with when you're in spirit form. In fact, he’s the one who helped you materialize in the realm of the living in the first place! So, it’s only fair that he also provides hints in order to steer you in the right direction. And I’ve gotta say, these hints are really well-written. For the most part, the devs do an excellent job of doling out cryptic hints that offer great satisfaction when you figure out just what you’re supposed to do next and why. There were one or two moments where I had absolutely no clue, but I’d rather that than an in-game line saying, “Hey, stupid. Go look in the thing and do the thing.” And I doubt anyone could be perfect at this, but this team got d<3<3<3-near close to perfection in my opinion. 

To aid you further in figuring out what to do next, the devs also added a feature where each character has their own unique ability that is relevant to the story, as well as to their overall characterization. I will say, though, some of these are more useful than others. That being said, it’s a really interesting feature that encourages further immersion in the world of the game. Along the way, the other characters also reveal information about the presumably dead captain, and as you learn more about who you’re really playing as, her spirit starts to materialize more and her ability to interact with and impact the environment around the rest of the characters increases. F<3<3<3ing brilliant!

There are so many good things to say about this game. The writing is strong. There are some really nice twists in the plot that, while you may or may not see them coming, d<3<3<3 will you be thrilled to be on one hell of a ride! But the shining star of the writing would have to be the characterization. Each character has so much depth, which is a crowning achievement, considering there are 11 characters (including the captain and Paulo). But oh my goodness! Some of these characters and the shtuff they’ve been through had me absolutely weeping and fighting back the desire to Persona 4 my way through my computer screen to give them the biggest effing hug my spindly arms could muster! The amount of care and attention that went into crafting each character pays off immensely in making this an intriguing murder mystery. Every character has motivations for being on this ship, and none of them are willing to divulge everything, let alone be truthful even when it’s apparent that someone actually murdered the captain. 

Another strong element in this game is the atmosphere. If there are any retro fans out there, just think Earthbound. Everything from the text boxes to the character designs to the midi-style soundtrack just screams retro. Heck, I’m sold!

Finally, let’s talk about quite possibly the best part of this game. The soundtrack. I’m a bit of a music nerd. Some might say snob. Those people will be dealt with accordingly. But my God! This soundtrack is incredible. Bill Kiley does an amazing job of staying on brand with the retro vibes while still creating complex musical compositions that do a whole lot of heavy lifting! Each character has his or her own musical theme, and none of them are just a simple motif that gets repeated ad nauseum. We have actual instrumentation to bless our earholes! For example, Marcurio’s theme has voices singing in a very dramatic operatic style, which is actually a very relevant choice once you learn a little bit more about what makes that guy tick. 

And can I just gush about Donovan’s theme? That is my new pump-up jam! And the pacing of when you actually have unfettered access to that theme is perfection itself! Without spoiling anything, Donovan becomes accessible at a very crucial moment in the game’s plot, and having his theme play as you’re figuring things out and piecing the mystery together was a brilliant choice. 

I don’t say this often. Maybe only once before in one of my reviews. But this game deserves a higher price tag. The game itself takes several hours to complete, especially if, like me, you really immerse yourself in the mystery and settle in for a thrilling ride. On top of that, there are multiple endings. And, like, the overall presentation – the way various elements, all so strong in their own rights, come together and crystallize so magnificently – is so satisfying to me both as a retro video game fan and as a murder mystery fan. Seriously, how can I give you more of my money?!

author: {'steamid': '76561198054358936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1655167080}
review:
This was a suspenseful mystery game with a really creative and unique gameplay mechanic! The ability to possess different people in order to solve the mystery made this a story that could not be told in any other medium. The characters all had a good amount of depth, and the story got pretty dark at times but never felt gratuitously edgy. If you like mysteries, definitely give this game a try!

My only complaint is that there's a really annoying glitch where your character gets stuck in the wall between two floors. This happened about five times when I was playing, so I'd recommend saving often so you don't lose a ton of progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198815381397', 'num_games_owned': 114, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1661875117}

author: {'steamid': '76561198251043256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1659790917}
review:
Has its fair share of bugs (there was one point where during a key point in dialogue immediately before the ending, I teleported outside of the walls of the ship), but nothing that a bit of fiddling around with the game wouldn't fix. Let down by the graphics a bit, especially in the endings, where characters can literally witness people being shot directly in front of them without a single emotion on their faces. A lot of it felt kind of rushed, but maybe I just prefer a slower pacing. Also would have benefited from a few quality of life improvements - I never quite got the hang of saving, and would've also preferred not having to detour to the dining room every time I wanted to save, and an ability to skip dialogue would've helped immensely, especially when playing the final confrontation 5 times for all the endings. I suppose some mysteries always go unanswered, but I would've liked more closure on the player character - do they pass on? Is their body ever found? Maybe it's a function of the possession system, like in Ghost Trick, but it weirdly doesn't feel like the player character is at all that fleshed out.

However, for the most part, despite all this, the game really worked! I found the mysteries compelling, I liked the influence/possession system. I enjoyed learning more about these characters, especially Quella and Darryl (although I wish more characters had the psychological confrontations that Darryl and Gwen had, I also get that they had a LOT more going on psychologically than the rest of the non-villainous main cast), and I liked the power system. Kind of like Disco Elysium, where you're brought in to investigate one dead body and suddenly you're talking to cryptids and trying to resolve decades old political beef, this is one of those games that starts off with a fairly small scale premise (solve your own murder) and then branches out substantially by the end. If you can look past some of the flaws, which I clearly did since I played this game to 100% completion, I think there's a really neat little game here. It's fairly brief and inexpensive, so I'd recommend giving it a shot for anyone into short closed room mysteries that go a little off the rails at the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250224486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1508526451}
review: This game is CRIMINALLY UNDERRATED.  It is legitamtely one of the more interesting and charming games on Steam that I've encountered in my years using this platform for gaming, and II can't fathom how it could not be more of a popular game.  It is one of the few mystery-oriented games that actually made me care about figuring out the truth behind not only the player's death, but about everything else going on in the game's story. It also reminds me of Ghost Trick, both in premise and in feel., though both go in vastly different directions. The characters, story, and concepts are more than enough to warrant this game being more popular, to the point that I would consider it a criminal offense to not give it a try, especially for its price.

review: Starts as a cute Earthbound-esque ghosty game and quickly evolves into an intense 999-esque murder mystery. Really wasn't a fan of any of the endings (the answers to the twists & the means of getting there were satisfying, but the endings themselves felt extremely abrupt with multiple loose ends unaddressed and basically no time to emotionally process the ramifications of the culprits), but overall this was an very well-written character adventure game. Check it out if you're a fan of 999 and/or Maniac Mansion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124901879', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1641277643}
review: Why Am I Dead At Sea is a mystery game as exciting as it is nostalgic. I played through this gem over five years ago, and just finished a second complete playthrough, reminding me of how great this game truly is. I was a huge fan of both the pixel graphics and chiptune soundtracks, though this sort of thing really depends on the person. Nevertheless, the pacing and storytelling was excellent, really giving each character some satisfying development as the mystery unfolded. All that for only five bucks? What a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172681923', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1626103663}
review:
Why Am I Dead At Sea is the true thematic and spiritual successor to EarthBound and Mother 3, unfairly overshadowed by Undertale, released only 4 months after this game. But that's neither here nor there. What matters is that this game is a story-telling masterpiece; a simultaneously disturbing and heart-wrenching character study that examines the struggles and horrors that occur during our everyday lives that, more often than not, we are completely oblivious to. The narrative forces players to question their own place in the world as well as those of others around them. 

The game revolves around you, a ghost aboard the S.S. Douce Amere, possessing the ship's passengers in order to uncover clues about your death through initiating conversations with other characters. At the same time, you will learn more about these characters' personalities, motivations and personal lives. In essence, the gameplay loop boils down to interacting with characters and objects. Thankfully, the cast of this game is well-developed, multifaceted and realistic, and by the end, the player's connection with all of them will be so strong that they will feel like real people. All of this is accompanied by beautiful pixel graphics in the same style as EarthBound/Mother and a soulful, haunting soundtrack that is just as varied, engaging and touching as the characters themselves. 

I know the term "hidden gem" is tossed around a lot nowadays and has lost some of its meaning as a result. However, if there is one game that truly fits the definition of "hidden gem", it's this one. Peltast Software have created a work of art with this game. I'm not sure where they are or what they're up to now, but I sincerely hope to see more from them in the future. 

In short, this is the best book I, and hopefully you, will ever play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022465409', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1494925743}
review: its good!

author: {'steamid': '76561199069703943', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1625520946}
review: This is an indie game that I bought for only $5 and it became one of my favorite games of all time. I've 100%'ed this game and gotten all achievements and endings and its the best mystery game I've ever played. While playing this game, you'll see that almost every single character is insanely interesting and it could honestly be any of them. Though it seems light, it is pretty dark for a five dollar pixel indie game. One piece of advice I have for everyone playing this game is that there are different endings and chances are that you wont fully solve the mystery and get the first picture in one playthrough. Since playthroughs are pretty short I would recommend playing a second time and consulting a guide if necessary (make sure it doesnt spoil anything) rather than just looking up what you think you missed because its a great plottwist/ending. TLDR: I cant recommend this game enough

author: {'steamid': '76561197998583761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1622440119}

author: {'steamid': '76561198107258071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1616011674}
review:
I would have preferred to recommend this game.  It was fascinating, the mechanics are something I've never seen before, and I always like to support games that do something different.  For the price, it was well worth it so if you're even a little curious then I would suggest you check it out.  The characters are fleshed out and interesting and I found something compelling about each one (yes, even that one), and the game tackles many dark themes with respect for them.  (My only sore point there was thinking one of the guys had a husband for a hot second and getting really excited, but then it was a predictable plot element that was well handled, but extremely played out and unoriginal.)

That said, the bugs absolutely kill it.  I enjoyed the quick movement speeds, but I lost out on progress constantly because I got stuck or characters got stuck on geometry and couldn't make it to locations where I needed them.  There was a really solid hint system towards the beginning of the game that I enjoyed, but towards the end things kind of fell apart and lost the consistent thread of revelation, so it became this chore of "warg into X, check for dialogue, warg into Y, check for dialogue, warg into Z, check for dialogue, warg back into X," rinse repeat, until I looked up a walkthrough to discover that some dialogue cues actually weren't showing up for me to start with.  To top it all off, when I finally got to the end, the game crashed on the final cutscene.

So this review is being posted in the heat of frustration and disappointment and I may soften it later, but having to look up the ending on YouTube because the game won't run is I think a tragic cap-off to a game this otherwise nuanced and exceptional.  I would still say buy it, it's not expensive and it supports a game of rare style and quality (apart from its shortcomings), just be aware going in that these frustrating moments exist and you may get very unlucky with your finale to this experience.  It at least seems like that largely hasn't been the case.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998481519', 'num_games_owned': 919, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1615864232}
review:
As much as I'd like to, I can't recommend this game as-is. I encountered glitches where my character was stuck out of bounds after going up or down stairs, and lost progress several times. That, combined with the lack of quality-of-life features in terms of getting all the endings, meant I was fighting the game more than I was playing it.

It's good when it works, but it's too broken to work consistently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034215057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1615836369}
review:
Holy molly, Why Am I Dead At Sea beated my every expectation. It's a short game, just around 4 hours of gameplay for me, but it's very good!

Word of caution: You should download the kind of, but not really, free prequel from the creators, called Why Am I Dead: http://www.peltastsoftware.com/content.html?id=waid, it'll help you a lot to understand this game, and the story.

Basically, you're a ghost with no recollection of what happened to you, or who you are. You're in a boat, and a kid is able to speak to you. From this point forward, you'll have to get inside people's bodies to try to control their movement, but not their actions, you're just a push in their inner mind to actually say something. As you learn about the diverse characters, you'll be able to haunt them, deepen the plot, and understand more about what transcurred in the ship.

It can feel kind of like a puzzle, sometimes you might not be really sure what your next step should be, and that's where a certain character will be able to help you, so you don't get stuck. You'll be able to reach the ending easily, or if you're a bit slower, with patience. Now, reaching the different endings requires more deep thinking and certain actions, and I recommend you saving just before finishing the game for certain reasons.

Why Am I Dead At Sea doesn't think the player is stupid. It doesn't hand hold you. It expects you to think hard, and remember evidences. Do not get discouraged by the price, the length or the graphics. It's a very especial experience that is really beautiful and will stay with me for a long time. I have to warn you that it might trigger certain vulnerable people.

I recommend this game, and it's in my hopes that you'll play it from beginning to ending in a single day. Non-stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067862153', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1539619092}

author: {'steamid': '76561199012847805', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1588822699}
review:
Pretty neat murder mystery; it was interesting to learn more about each character while also trying to figure out how you died. 

However, parts of the game were frustratingly unintuitive. For most of the game, you have to talk to a specific character while possessing a different character. Sometimes, it wasn't obvious who you were supposed to possess/talk to, and going through every possible permutation feels like a waste of time. 

Otherwise, great story and fun music, would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000917649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 1278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1278, 'last_played': 1609544322}
review:
Странная игра. С одной стороны - необычный детектив об убийстве на корабле. Причем, расследуем мы его благодаря тому, что можем вселяться духом в других людей и заставлять их разговаривать с другими людьми.

С другой стороны - скучная и неудобная механика игры, при которой нужно много бегать по кораблю разными персонажами, искать, с кем бы поговорить в каждом конкретном случае, какие предметы можно изучить и т.д. Т.е. играть в это совершенно скучно и неприятно. При том, что история - в целом прикольная.

_Не рекомендую_ тем, кто любит игры за хороший геймплей. Рекомендую тем, кто любит читать детективы и не против побегать по кораблю пиксельными персонажами туда-сюда, чтобы почитать все доступные диалоги.

author: {'steamid': '76561198258794986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1599330240}

author: {'steamid': '76561198184877226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1608185673}
review:
I loved the story and trying to figure out the truth. I knew who is who in the ending but gosh darn, finding a way to prove it was difficult! XD

Save your game smarty. I ran into glitches and bugs a whole lot. Best to use all 3 slots for your first run to save at various points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130402546', 'num_games_owned': 628, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1607103768}
review:
A really fun and interesting game where you play as a recently deceased ghost who with the help of a psychic child can go around possessing the crewmates and  passengers to reveal the mystery of your death.

All characters have something to hide and the game while isn't super hard doesn't make it easy find the culprit. You get to learn more about each characters and unveil their past and the whole process was engaging and I enjoyed it.

If there is a flaw for this game.... (game story spoilers of course) [spoiler]I really disliked the fact that we don't get any final scenes with the MC and/or Paolo in the endings, it just cuts to the rest of the case (sans Paolo unless it's the worst ending, another issue I have) and we just gonna assume the MC moved on and it kind of dampens the experience for me but overall still enjoyed the game.[/spoiler]

Overall though a nice game and I hope more people can try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097722549', 'num_games_owned': 1620, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 842, 'last_played': 1606680867}
review:
This game was an awesome experience. I did not think when starting my playthrough that I would enjoy this game as much as I later did, since the only real gameplay revolves around dialogue. I was very wrong, since this games tells an incredible story and it contains different endings as well. I have experienced them all, and it's cool that they change depending on how much dialogue you have read before the finale. The soundtrack also changes depending on which character you are controlling. Furthermore, characters have different attributes and skills, which are useful in different situations. 

Sometimes a guide may be needed to progress, but I advice you to take your time and talk to as many characters as possible at all times. It is very satisfying to see the story progress and later experience its ending(s). For only 4 Euro, this game is a must have!

author: {'steamid': '76561198061572167', 'num_games_owned': 431, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1605661109}

review: It has almost Agatha Christie feeling, just more sinister and a bit more supernatural. Puzzles built around possessing different npcs are neat. And characters have pretty decent amount of depth. Very good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198823673661', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1701371760}
review: This is one of the best mystery stories that I've ever played or watched. Every character is suspicious and unlike most murder mysteries, you don't know who it is by the halfway point. The soundtrack and plot are amazing, the game rarely crashes, and you will always be interested with what's going on in the game. On top of that the game has 5 endings and nothing is more satisfying that unlocking all of them. This game is absolutely worth five dollars and for sure more than that. If you want a great mystery game for 5 dollars I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168814735', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1651021987}
review:
Why Am I Dead At Sea is a wonderfully somber game about murder, money, and motivation.

Pros:
-An extremely compelling story, absolutely worth playing through every possible way.
-Characters that you'll either love or love to hate.
-Speaking of characters, their backstories, personalities, and motivations. They all have one or two things grating away at their minds, and it's wonderful to learn about everything they think about.
-Very clever mechanics in terms of being a spirit and moving the alive passengers down the right path.
-The special abilities of the alive passengers are all pretty cool also... at least, the ones that assist in gameplay/story.

Cons:
-It can be a little tedious to move back and forth through the rooms, but the map is fairly small so it's not that big of a con.
-The "correct path" isn't straightforward as a story-based game like this should probably be. Thankfully, there's a character you meet early on named Paulo who can help you in the right direction. However, in the final chapter you can no longer ask Paulo for help. The puzzles in that chapter are extremely out-of-the-box, but I admit I'm kind of dumb, so take that with a grain of salt.
-There are 4 endings. (or 5, if you count the two versions of the bad ending) This on its own is cool, but if you miss one piece of evidence, you may not be able to get every ending on your first save file. I was able to get two of the 4 endings, but the other two required a piece of evidence that I had no idea even existed. So yes, I did not 100% this game, but that comes down to me not wanting to start the game over, despite it being very possible to beat within the span of a day.
-There's a lot of out-of-bound glitches I ran into, meaning I had to reload my save file. One time this happened, I was sent back an entire chapter. This mainly happens around stairs.

Overall, this game is something you should experience. It's absolutely worth playing, despite the flaws. It may be frustrating at points, but damn is the payoff sweet.

The price is fine as is. If you REALLY want to save money, feel free to wait for a sale, but the tag is worth the experience. And really, you're playing for the story, not the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199010306395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1601174963}
review:
I thought this was pretty good; the story was intriguing. Definitely has that whodunit vibe which was great. Good value for a fairly low price.

I was hoping for more inventory puzzles and evidence collecting, like in traditional detective games. This game focused more on interrogations and the people/suspects involved. Makes sense, I suppose, since you're a ghost and can't interact with much on your own. The special powers you get as a ghost certainly lent a different way to investigate.

If I could suggest an improvement, I'd have liked a map that shows where all the characters are on the ship. I feel like I spent a lot of time hunting down the person I was looking for since the characters do move on their own.

Had fun, highly recommend it if you're interested in a different detective experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012191490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1601169316}
review: Just like the flash game it was a sequel to, an excellent game. The plot line was interesting, and inhabiting people as a ghost was a neat game play feature. I did run into some bugs, but a quick restart/reload ended up fixing them. Overall, I would definitely recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042755781', 'num_games_owned': 1309, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1600429805}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105964694', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1600075570}
review:
It's actually a simple and straightforward story, but the progress of uncovering all the mysteries is so suspenseful and attractive.
Sometimes it's too slow-moving, e.g. some character's dialogue

Some bads about the games:
[spoiler] It's weird of Donovan to approach and chit-chat with others since the talking is unnecessary and doesn't fit his character. And he is unnecessarily toxic.[/spoiler]
Some bugs like stuck in the black areas, or characters stand by the door in their room so I can't enter it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261881798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1599765403}
review:
Oh man, I was not expecting this one

I have to admit I bought this game because I had the spare cash after purchasing another one (that I didn't like, but will not name it)

This is the type of game that I like to call "an experience" because there's nothing quite like it.

Every character is not what it seems and is hiding something, every discovery you make brings forth another, the place is small and makes it engaging, the twists and turns are at every corner...

If I knew this game was going to grip me like that I would've paid more for it. It's that good

author: {'steamid': '76561198064451677', 'num_games_owned': 1409, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1677473540}
review: Why Am I Dead At Sea is a mystery/adventure game about you finding out how you died. To find out how you died the player character is a ghost that has the power to possess characters to investigate the miss happenings on the ship. Along with that comes fairly complex characters each with their own set of issues and backstory. The game is fairly short and can be beaten in like a hour or so if you know what you're doing as I put in two playthroughs in my overall 6 hours of playtime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057670836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1609107931}
review:
One of the best written and engaging games I've played in a long while, I would strongly recommend if you have a day to kill. The story and gameplay feel very fresh, even though you're playing a linear narrative it always feels open ended, you never feel like you're searching for the one piece of the puzzle you're missing, instead you keep discovering new pieces and how they all organically end up fitting together. 

Although wholly unnecessary, I would recommend checking out the spoiler-free guide once you reach the point where the game strongly hints that you save. At that point there're some things that are easy to miss and it's helpful to reload to that point and pick up on what you may not have explored blind. 

All in all great gameplay, engaging writing and story, and fantastic music (by the great Bill Kiley!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198168973548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1025, 'last_played': 1533693680}

author: {'steamid': '76561198121801651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1652851038}
review:
Wonderfully written characters and a thrilling plot. If you like dialogue-driven stories then this is the perfect purchase! The dialogue is fantastic. I loved learning more about these characters as I went on. The twists were amazing and well written! I loved trying to guess what was going on ahead of the characters. And there is a ton of flavor text that can help clue you in on characters' intentions and backstories. There was a bug, (character glitching through a wall after walking up a staircase and getting stuck), but it didn't happen often. Made sure to save frequently just in case I had to reload!

Overall fantastic game! Amazingly written story and fantastic characters. Sucks you in and keeps you invested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198880563663', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1337, 'last_played': 1592548023}
review:
If you like games with puzzles and mysteries with great atmosphere then I suggest you check out this game. You'll find many interesting twist and turns in the plot which will leave you in shock and maybe even awe. at least it did for me anyways. I don't want to spoil too much, so I won't. I will admit at times the puzzles get rather confusing and occasionally tedious to figure out. But That could have just been me being dumb. Regardless I highly suggest you check it out if you like mystery games with good atmosphere. 
Oh also you play as a ghost, and that itself makes the game pretty rad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152442156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 865, 'last_played': 1594917771}

review: O game é bem elaborado e a trama é complexa. Os personagens tem perfis complicados e é realmente difícil ter uma ideia prematura de quem é o verdadeiro criminoso e dos motivos. Recomendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049940473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 287, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1589756092}
review:
Excellent little game with two major weaknesses, which you mustn't let spoil your experience. One, glitches cause lost progress - save frequently! Two, the interplay between mechanics & plot reveals becomes increasingly convoluted and hard to keep track of  - so you may eventually need to check a guide as it's not a take it slow, keep notes kind of game. 

Accept these faults and you will find excellent writing & story, and a great mystery - all achieved through impressively limited & atypical means. Much appreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198346990023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1589141316}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970952979', 'num_games_owned': 2552, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1590363267}
review:
Underneath the 8bit veneer is a lot of clever structure and dialogue with some very surprisingly heavy themes. At first the scale of the ship and the number of doors is overwhelming, as is the realisation that you aren't looking to talk to each character but each character AS each other character!  and that's before later abilities become clear.

For the most part though it's surprisingly manageable, each is unlocked in turn and generally the next step is easy to work out but not thrown in your face. I only got stuck once.  Feeling like I've figured most things out and that progression is natural is a sign of great writing. 

The characters are great, each has a lot of flesh to their personality that you'll chew through eventually, and the mystery has a few layers and twists going on, it took a while for me to feel invested in the story but I got there.  Some of the themes are darker and deeper than expected and they can suddenly come out of left field but they fit, they don't feel out of place and they give a deeper investment to the story as a whole.

Some of the mechanics are wonderfully clever and really squeeze some unexpected ingenuity out of a very limited toolkit. I would say it's a bit of a letdown that a lot of the abilities are completely useless, even some that feel like they should lead to some major clues.  The read/unread dialogue feature is frequently buggy which is annoying, and a hold-to-speed-through-text button would be a godsend

On the downside, there are some combinations of dialogue which don't make sense (e.g. discussing Gwen.. as Gwen) and I'll say outright the endings are unsatisfying. The story truly felt like there was another layer and another chapter to go through which would turn some things on their head but alas the conclusion hits you at speed and the finale is awkward.  Trying to hunt the endings was incredibly frustrating and felt like that part was rushed, a real shame.  Closure is.. definitely lacking, too.

As a tldr, slow start and the ending is unsatisfying but I'd still say the journey was fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198860080666', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1676813259}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971026151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1584852221}
review:
Another reviewer more or less described this game as the result of Ace Attorney and Ghost Trick having a baby raised by Earthbound, and that's apt. The art style is [i]very[/i] reminiscent of the Mother series and despite manual control over characters, it is effectively a visual novel. 

It's presentation is largely welcoming and much of the dialogue is humorous, but it is immediately apparent that the narrative contains dark elements. Sometimes, this presents itself in ways that are gratuitous, but mostly, the insidious elements are well-woven into the characters. (This game does not appear to be rated by the ESRB, but I suspect it would be rated "Mature" for "Blood, Violence, Sexual Themes, and Strong Language". Players sensitive to topics such as suicide, sex abuse, torture, and murder should be forewarned.)

[i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] has the same pitfalls of all visual novels and adventure games, which is that the player must often resort to exhausting every dialogue option to advance the plot. Exhausting the dialogue trees is especially exhausting when you are more than one person. Every person has different things to say depending on whom you are possessing and just how deeply you are possessing them, and hunting for the one flag can be tedious. With that said, the game provides visual indicators of what characters have something new to say, which alleviates the slog.

The game does have some bugs, however. Some of them make it unclear which options in a dialogue tree have been previously chosen, which causes the player to unnecessarily revisit some content. Most damning was a bug I encountered early on that caused the character I was controlling to race up two flights of stairs and soft-lock the game. Ultimately, these were an annoyance for me, but not a deal-breaker. The old adage holds: "Save early, and save often!" (And don't worry about missing significant content by saving after an event. There's very little you can miss in this way.)

A review often seeks to answer "Is it worth the money?" Yes. I purchased the game when it was only $1, but even had I payed full price (still only $5), I would have gotten my money's worth. That said, I think the better question amid the thousands of games available to a player is "Is it worth the time?"

Yes, again. This game isn't any longer than it needs to be, and a significant percentage of the play time is discovering new things about what is happening on the ship and who the characters are. They are all deeply troubled, and many of them appear to be well-established tropes, but none of them are one-dimensional, and many of them are dynamic. The endings were a little lackluster - especially because there are technically five of them, but the journey is interesting. The conversation the game has with the player has value.

Whether you are undecided or think you'll be really into this, I recommend first playing the developer's original flash game, [i]Why Am I Dead?[/i] - or rather, the superior remake [i]Why Am I Dead:Rebirth[/i]. Its characters are not as fleshed out, and the scenario is not as well-developed, but it has a similar feel and appearance, and it delivers its payload within a much shorter period of time. (Also, the true ending of [/i]Rebirth[i] ties in with this game. Mind the bugs, though! It does have some issues that can force a player to restart.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198102248563', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1584846014}
review: When I played the flash game and found out the same guys were developing a sort of "sequel", I was hyped, and as soon as I found it on Steam, around 5 years ago, I added it to my wishlist. Now, honestly, I just wished I had bought it sooner. It's everything the flash game is, but better

author: {'steamid': '76561198217873204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1696827535}
review: Why Am I Dead At sea is an interesting murder mystery where you play as the spirit of the murder victim trying to piece together what exactly happened and who exactly you are. This game has the same charm as Earthbound for the SNES without the combat (which is good because it allows for the focus of this game to solely be on the story). I have been taking this game in by pieces which leaves me super excited to see how it unravels. It isn't a really long game and can be marathon'd in a day with no real difficulty. But do yourself the favor and take it in piece by piece and the story will feel incredibly rewarding.

review:
Real fun and engrossing story, interesting concepts, and plenty of plot twists and turns. 

Not going to spoil it, but it's not your straightforward murder mystery story. The added element of being a ghost with no memories only adds interesting gameplay elements as you peek into the minds of the passengers, and find ways around puzzles with your abilities.

I can easily see myself playing the game again soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301752608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1578389638}
review:
遊戲設計頗有巧思，過程非常紮實、有趣，給我非常好的遊戲體驗。
可惜結尾的設計稍有遺憾，主要是蒐集全結局所需的重複試誤有點枯燥，結局本身的滿足感也稍微比不上前面的遊戲過程。到了後期，不斷切換附身角色去和不同角色互動的過程，也需要一些耐性。
但是，整體而言，瑕不掩瑜，是個值得一玩的傑出作品。以此價位來說，也是非常划算。

author: {'steamid': '76561198369952763', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1578167950}
review:
Hmm... I have mixed feelings about this game, but overall I don't regret playing it.

First of all, the concept is great. I love the idea of slowly finding out who you are, and your conversations with the boy who can see ghosts, as well as taking control of people in order to use their conversations to talk to others. Using everyone's special abilities was cool in most cases (some were kinda useless, but my favorites were probably Quella's - added a lot of character information by identifying tone of voice - and Ferdinand's - a bunch of silly "announcements" that made me laugh). The mystery was fairly interesting, and it was reasonably satisfying to root out the evil goings-on on the ship, particularly as you piece together clues little-by-little and start realizing what's going on.

However, the reason I say I have mixed feelings is because the game is not without its flaws. Despite the engaging nature of the concept, the actual gameplay is rather unintuitive, and as one review pointed out, your only real strategy is trying to exhaust all your dialogue between every character, and with all the characters constantly moving around, this can be a pain, especially when you gain the ability to fully possess people, which unlocks even more conversation options. This was somewhat amended by being able to ask Paulo for hints when it seemed entirely non-obvious about what you should do next, but unfortunately you can't always do that, or he'll sometimes give you hints that only cover stuff you've already done. Chapters 4 and 5 were absolutely the most frustrating in this regard, and I ended up having to consult a walkthrough to figure out what I was supposed to do next. Some sort of mental journal, where you could keep track of the information you've learned in an organized manner, would have greatly helped things, since it's nearly impossible to keep every bit of dialogue in your head, especially when some things turn out to be red herrings. It doesn't help that the game doesn't appear to have been entirely bug-tested, seeing as while walking around normally I glitched into walls three separate times and became trapped in the black area, being forced to restart from my last save. On a similar note, sometimes characters that were supposed to follow you would get stuck places and refuse to come with you, forcing you to reboot the game so they'd walk in a different place. Another frustration was that sometimes the UI would indicate that you hadn't explored a conversation topic with one person when you already had, or even worse, sometimes crucial evidence inexplicably wasn't in bold as an unexplored talking point, so you'd walk around believing you already had spoken to that person about everything.

Finally, let's get to the part of the game that I found both positive and negative points in: the characters. I'll say what I can without spoiling things, and everything else will be spoiler-tagged. Overall, the game appears to have been playing with the idea of morally-grey characters, which is a concept that I think has been well-explored in other mystery-style games I've enjoyed, such as Ghost Trick, Hotel Dusk, Ace Attorney, and Danganronpa. However, a lot of the characters that fell into the morally-grey category came off as unlikable, even if you could feel a degree of sympathy for the situation they were in. 

Example: [spoiler]Marcurio speaks of his abusive childhood and how it shaped him into being a seriously messed-up person, but it doesn't really excuse him taking extremely suspicious bribes without question and pinning the murder on Gwen, who he knew was innocent - particularly since Gwen also experienced an abusive childhood that was possibly even worse and didn't take it out on the people around her, other than her investigation of Donovan, which was arguably justified and provoked by the true killer anyway. The fact that he admits that he's a bad person in the good ending is an improvement, but nonetheless...[/spoiler] 

Example 2, and this one especially: [spoiler]Even though Donovan was a massive jerk, I was all set up to like him as an interesting character despite his meanness, since his dogged search for the truth indicated to me that he was a good person at heart who believed in truth and justice. Unfortunately, him coming back at the end and threatening to murder every man on the ship pretty much killed my respect for his sense of justice, and it was especially frustrating that characters seemed to forgive him and say he didn't deserve to die from his subsequent suicide even though he'd casually said he'd kill them all without mercy.[/spoiler]

On top of this, I thought it was rather strange that the game portrayed Alton as [spoiler]basically forgiving Xu by saying "I know we've had our differences" when the day before she took advantage of his crush on her to steal from him, lied about it, and then when he confronted her she told him he basically deserved it because he was privileged. Like Marcurio, I appreciated that she seemed to come to terms at least somewhat that she wasn't a good person, but I really couldn't understand Alton's complete lack of bitterness a day after he had a self-loathing mental breakdown.[/spoiler]

Finally, last negative about the characters, specifically, the main one. Like Ghost Trick, you will eventually find out who you were when you were alive. Unlike Ghost Trick, you are given almost no personality of your own, and everything about your personality is told to you by other people instead of you being able to actually experience it. The circumstances of your death are eventually revealed, but you are given no closure as to what happens to your ghost afterward in any ending. So it's incredibly difficult to get invested in who you are as a character at all, especially when there are many things about your character's past that are left completely open-ended and not explained.

All right, that was a lot of negative stuff, and I apologize, because I didn't feel entirely negative about the characters in the game. In particular, I was quite fond of Quella, Darryl, and Gwen. Quella's the most genuinely nice character in the entire game, a cheery people person who gets on well with nearly everyone and is luckily saved from being some sort of Mary Sue/manic pixie dream girl by suffering her own deep-seated insecurities about her writing and, well, some other things you'll have to find out. Darryl is a man who you will just desperately want to feel better, a ball of depression and self-hatred that you can eventually get to the bottom of with the aid of Quella, and I felt that Quella and Darryl had some of the most poignant and enjoyable conversations of the game. Quella's conversations with Gwen, a shy, extremely paranoid woman who's clearly been through hell with people who have hurt her, are a close second, and I like to imagine the three of them as the best of friends. Darryl and Gwen also had some of the most compelling segments of the game that were entirely optional, and was a really interesting way that allowed you as the player to help them overcome their trauma. I won't spoil it, but let's just say I recommend that when you get a lot of your memories back, you go talk to them while you're in ghost form.

I purchased Why Am I Dead At Sea during the Steam Winter Sale because I read a review describing it as the lovechild of Ace Attorney and Ghost Trick if their child was raised by EarthBound, and that description was enough to make me interested. However, it doesn't quite live up to any of their legacies - it lacks the whacked-out quirkiness of EarthBound, and doesn't have as many compelling characters (as well as lacking much of the humor, though the game does have its moments) as Shu Takumi's aforementioned adventure games. However, for the fun of the concept and the three characters I did end up caring about, if you're into a bit of an atypical mystery game, it might be worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201613371', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1577867137}
review:
Why am I dead at sea is a fantastic murder mystery that is heavily focused on the story aspect. You don’t know who you are, you don’t know why you are here, all you know is that you were killed by someone on the ship and you need to find them before the journey ends and they escape and everyone disappears. This story has multiple endings.

The controls are deceptively simple, you just use the “Z” “X” “C” keys and WSAD or the arrow keys to move around, “Z” to interact with people or things, “X” to possess or inhabit someone’s body, and “C” to use that individuals special skill, such as looking through pockets and peeking through doors. 

This game does have some negative aspects though, during my playthroughs twice I got stuck with the stairs. Once I moved right instead of left and got stuck outside the barrier on the stairs, and the second time I moved left far too quickly and broke through the barrier on the other side, so I could walk around in the dark parts of the screen. Needless to say, please save your game often unless you are in the 4th chapter to get all endings. 
Another negative aspect was the endings. Once you find out who the killer is you get a cutscene where everyone is outside the ship all thankful to be alive, but there is no info on what happens to you. No fading away into the afterlife, no goodbyes to the few you actually manage to communicate with, no nothing. You don’t show up anymore and credits roll. No idea what happens to everyone else or you, it’s pretty disappointing. 

All and all I hesitantly recommend this game because of the abrupt and unsatisfying endings, If I could give it a “Meh” option I would.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215620676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1592437967}
review: Very intriguing and got me super invested to the point I almost played the entire thing in one sitting. A super good story with some very neat twists and mechanics at work. Only ran into a couple glitches, but nothing too terrible (as long as you save often so you can reload before the glitch.) Definitely recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198131051854', 'num_games_owned': 864, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1576915346}
review:
It's like Ghost Trick, but with more active detective work, and it takes place on a ship. Really good story and characters though, it really delivers! 

I feel bad getting this game on sale, it's definitely worth way more than the base price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198095293908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1556583281}
review: This is an over all good game. The mechanics are unique and enjoyable and the story is just amazing. I can't go into much deal as spoiling the story would be a huge sin as the storytelling and characters are so interesting. I found myself invested in all of them. The only complaint I can think of is that the player character's story line doesn't get a finite end like all the other characters do. But the rest of the story is so good I don't feel it deserves too big of a complaint. Please check this game out it's a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060605195', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1588550917}
review:
Высветилась в предложке с 80% скидкой, купил без особого энтузиазма просто потыкать после учёбы. По итогу "просто потыкал" от начала и до конца не отрываясь, настолько захватывающим оказался сюжет. Если вы не имеете ничего против пиксельной графики и любите самобытные, атмосферные детективы с большим количеством сюжетных твистов - смело берите, получите 8-10 часов удовольствия.
Рекомендую.
