author: {'steamid': '76561198047278259', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1500760503}
review:
[h1] Wow. [/h1]
I did not expect that.
This might be one of the best indie games I have ever played.
In this game, you are a ghost trying to piece together your own murder case.
You do so by taking over the passengers and talking to each other.
Getting a whim of their personalities allows you to follow them around (you control their movement, but you can't relay information that you know through them).
After getting to know them intimately, you can finally possess them and speak through their mouths, relaying that information that you've pieced together through other characters and exploring the ship.
This game throws a lot of twists into the story. Some bigger, some smaller.
Some fairly predictable.
It keeps you interested throughout. It's a game that you can't really put down until you finish it.
Something that I really enjoyed was the Mindreading mechanic.
It doesn't really advance the plot (which is sad, cause that would've been kinda cool), but god is it aesthetic. 
The cat one is probably my favourite.
This game features multiple endings based on the evidence that you collect throughout your journey.
I recommend not looking at guides on how to get them until you finished the game once (don't worry, you can't really miss evidence until the very end. If you save, you can collect the rest of it before entering the finale).
Sometimes it can get kind of frustrating, in which case, look at a guide or keep trying.
The soundtrack is very memorable since its mostly tied to the characters. This gives every track a personal feel to it and it also helps giving life to the characters themselves. The melodies reflect their personalities.
The graphics have a very earthbound feel to them. They're fantastic for a pixel-art game.
The longer you play, the more do you get a feel for the ship, It's rooms, the character's usual hideouts.
One gripe I have with this game is that every character has his/her own special ability.
They really do range from kinda-, no - sorta-, nah, maybe important? to completely useless. 
For example, one character's ability is to see what other people have in their pockets.
Yeah. It's never used.
It's kinda sad actually. It could've been used for some cool evidence collecting.
Like, what if you look into someone's pocket and you find the protagonist's handkerchief in there?
Then you could point it out and they'd get all nervous, which could then later be used as evidence.
That's just an example. Not sure how you make the "take pills which make you run faster but also muddle up the screen" ability useful in collecting evidence. It just feels like a tacked on feature, which is sad. It could've been a pretty cool mechanic to be honest.
I've encountered one bug where Donnovan wouldn't meet me in his room and I'd be locked out. If that happens to you, just talk to him again and wait until he goes back to his room.
Now I'll get into spoilers, DON'T GO PAST HERE IF YOU HAVEN'T FINISHED THE GAME.
THE GAME IS FAIRLY CHEAP AND QUITE AN AMAZING JOURNEY.
SERIOUSLY, BUY IT.
PLAY IT.
PAST HERE IS NO-NO ZONE.




okay? good.

[spoiler] Some of the story twists really hit me. It really goes to show how indie devs write better stories than AAA companies with their millions of dollars. For once, I was really surprised to find out that the main character is female. I thought that that was a really neat twist. Adding that with her not only being the captain, but also a secret agent, she's a way more interesting character than I originally anticipated. I also like how every character tells you their own opinions on the captain. Again, it adds so much personality to these characters. They could've just as easily have every character say that she was really kind. The Donnovan twist was predictable as hell. I saw that coming from a mile away. That being said, he's used in a very interesting and cool way. When I took over Donnovan and that bloodpumping music started playing in the background, I grinned. You just feel so frickin' badass. And just as the Game Devs give you the Lollipop, they take it away and spit in your face. Before, I just thought that Donnovan was some kind of edgelord or really wanted revenge against the killer. But just those few moments you have with him, walking around with that music playing, knowing that he's an undercover cop, I immediately grew to love him. And then he dies (not really, but yaknow, I didn't know). I actually felt shocked and saddened. The Smilla/Donnovan Partners in Crime thing made that even worse. I'm amazed at how quickly they made me love a character who had zero appeal until then. Another thing that they could've improved is the showdown. Ferdinand just stands there and laughs while saying kinda predictable "Nyeh-eh I am the bad guy Muah-ha-ha" things. Also, Garv trying to pretend as if he's innocent and not really snapping out of it at any point until he tries to bribe a man who clearly has no need for money is EHHHHH. Also, they just kinda stand there and wait to get shot. Maybe one of them couldve taken a hostage or something. It may seem like I'm complaining a lot here, but I just intend to review games fairly. This game really touched me, it made me laugh, it made me hate (HOW DARE YOU DO THAT TO PAULO), It shocked me, surprised me and overall, I've had a great time with it.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198213853505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1499365999}
review: While glitchy, this game is a nice, short whodunit. I finished with most achievements in around 9 hours. The glitches at some points made me want to quit the game, but my desire to experience the story kept me going. Sometimes when interacting with items/surfaces the character would disappear completely or get sent into/stuck in the black areas of the level and I would have to go back to my last save game. I would only recommend this game to a person with patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140400162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1499562561}
review: 100% Recommend. Great story, characters, mystery. The music is phenomenal! This game is exactly what one should want from a Mystery game. My only qualm is the edges in the game catch you a lot and get you stuck. Everything else, GOLD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044557375', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1460064612}
review: It's not exceptional, but it definitely deserves at least a little more popularity than it gets. If you like exploring the glut of indie games there is here on Steam, have a little adventure and try this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037460297', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1498933315}
review:
It's sad to see how unapreciated this game is. If you like games where you solve a grand murder mystery this is a game for you. I loved the Mother-Styled graphics, It has great characters with a single exception that I wont mention to keep this spoiler free. It's fantastic how they keep such a small enviroment interesting throughout the whole game.
 
The game has a few cons: It has a few glitches and some typos, but nothing gamebreaking. Besides that, the music sometimes does not feel fitting for the setting of the game, it's not exacly bad, it just doesn't go with the mood. There were a few mechanics that are not used that had potencial, like the party, and mind reading.

Anyways, If you think you'll like this game, you probably will, at it's price, I think it's a must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083557114', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1498903966}
review:
Ich habe nicht erwartet, dass mich dieses Spiel derart packen würde! Die Grafik ist nicht so doll, der Sound gruselig, das Speichersystem unter aller Kanone (Es gibt drei Speicherslots und man speichert immer automatisch in den ersten, Man kann also nicht aktiv wählen, wohin man speichern möchte. Ich habe zu spät festgestellt, dass man im Startbildschirm den Speicherstand auch kopieren und in einen der anderen Speicherstände übertragen kann. Ist für meine Nachspieler vielleicht ein netter Hinweis.) Und immer mal wieder hängt einer der Charaktere irgendwo fest und lässt sich nur wieder lösen, wenn man im Quelltext des Speicherstands rum manipuliert...
Aber die Story ist wirklich erste Sahne und absolut mitreißend. Wir spielen einen Geist an Bord eines Schiffes. Dadurch ist der Spielraum natürlich begrenzt wie ein klassisches Kammerspiel, hat aber natürlich den Vorteil, dass man sich nach relativ kurzer Zeit sehr gut zurecht findet. Nach und nach lernen wir die Passagiere und Besatzungsmitglieder kennen und können sie mehr oder weniger manipulieren, um zu verstehen, was an Bord vor sich geht. (Jede der manipulierten Personen hat außerdem eine besondere Fähigkeit, die uns mehr oder weniger nutzen kann.) Irgendwas scheint hier nicht mit rechten Dingen zuzugehen. Wer sind wir eigentlich? Wer ist der Geist im Klo? Und wo zur Hölle ist eigentlich der Kapitän dieses Schiffes? Mit der Zeit habe ich das Spiel als sehr intensiv empfunden und habe über die Retrografik gar nicht mehr nachgedacht.
Es gibt mehrere Enden frei zu schalten. Um sie alle zu sehen, wird man vielleicht einen Guide zur Hilfe nehmen, aber mindestens eines zu erreichen, sollte kein Problem sein, da es keine unfair schweren Aufgaben gibt.
Wer gerne detektivisch rätselt, wird hier sicher auf seine Kosten kommen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320215235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1495511870}
review:
Why Am I Dead At Sea takes a simple concept (of what is essentially a point and click adventure minus clicking) and alters many core elements to make the game stand out among others in its genre. However, these were core elements for good reason, and the changes cause problems that are uncommon and jarring for the genre. But whatever the verdict, it's a unique ride all the way. 

The main draw to Why Am I Dead At Sea is its story. Without spoiling it, the basic premise is that the protagonist is a ghost (assumedly recently dead) trying to sort out, well, why it's dead at sea. This transforms the narrative into a murder mystery with a twist, as you can posses and manipulate the various characters during their own investigations. I personally love this mechanic. Instead of using a pointer, you'll control the ghost with a controller or in my case the keyboard. This makes the game significantly more interesting, since each character has a different ability, so once you unlock a new character you'll be able to explore the ship more efficiently (at least in most cases). Overall, this mechanic is the best part of the game. It makes playing the game more interesting than clicking and scrolling through text, it works well with the setting and tone of the game, and it combines some of the better parts of a first person and omniscent perspective without any narrative hiccups.

Speaking of the narrative, it does it's job well for a story rich game. The game is paced well, and has a great climax that will lead to one of the multiple endings. As far as the actual writing goes, you can learn a lot (I'd say a little too much) about characters and the mystery simply by reading the dialogue (which takes up most of the game). The characters are diverse, likable, and relatable, and the dialogue is well written. There are also a few missables that answer some questions that the main story never does.  And to top it all off, most of the characters' simple designs work with the visual style without seeming too basic. After all of this, it sounds like a perfect game, but unfortunately this isn't the case. 

My first problem in the game is that many of the mechanics are buggy. It's surprisingly easy to get stuck on a single pixel or clip through a wall, and since the game has manual saving, this can lead to loss of progress. I'd advise avoiding walls when you can ([spoiler]and not abusing the cats jumping ability[/spoiler]). To be fair, I only experienced issues twice in my two full playthroughs, but as both instances led to lost progress, I resent both of them.  

Secondly the narrative progression has some small issues due to the game mechanics. In most adventure games you'll expect a certain ammount of trial and error, but this game makes it much worse. Because each character is different, certain actions will only cause progression if done with a specific character. There is a speech bubble that will appear over a characters head when they have something to say to whoever you're controlling, but because you can only control characters one at a time (and the NPCs won't stay put while unpossesed), you may have to check each character, with every other character multiple times in order to progress. There is one chapter in which you must talk to one character with three different characters in order to progress to the next chapter. For this reason, I found myself possessing characters en masse and trapping them all in the observation room so I could check for new dialogue without having to walk back and forth between rooms. And what I discovered by using this strategy during my second playthrough was easily the most disappointing part of the game.

Now, the following contains pretty blunt spoilers. It does not contain any details that would spoil the plot, but this information will likely ruin the climax and any multiple playthroughs for you. In my case, ignorance was bliss, so I'd recommend skipping this part if you haven't played the game yet. However if you do intend to 100% the game, the following information is important.   [spoiler]Simply put, the different endings, aren't. There are two good endings, two bad endings, and the best ending. The good endings are nigh identical, the bad endings [b]are[/b] identical, and the best ending seems like a watered down combination of the good endings. Every ending answers all of the main games questions, so the only thing different about an ending will be parts of its dialogue. Furthermore, only the actions you take in the penultimate chapter affect the ending, although the game seems less linear than it actually is. With a guide (and no spoiler guides do exist) it is possible to play the game up to a point in the next to last chapter, save, and experience every ending from there by slightly altering your actions (which is how my second playthrough went). The multiple endings are easily the worst part of the game, as they encourage multiple playthroughs in a game that's best on the first play. The only rewards for reading through the same dialogue multiple times (i.e, 100% completion) are the achievements.[/spoiler] 

If you've made it to the end of this review, I'd simply like to specify that I do think Why Am I Dead At Sea is a good game. If you like this kind of game you'll definitely enjoy it, and if you don't it will likely change your mind. But in my case, I feel like I went in too deep (again) and ruined what was a fun experience for me by overthinking and overplaying it. If you're just looking for something new to play, I'd say go for it. If you intend 100% the game, or follow in my footsteps, approach with caution and reasonable expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006849221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1459995132}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045377617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1496902927}
review:
If you're a fan of murder mysteries, supernatural themes, or like character driven games with lots of text, I highly recommend this game. Heck, even if you're not a huge fan of those things I still would probably recommend this game! In Why Am I Dead At Sea, you explore a strange cruise ship as a murdered soul, learning bits about the passengers and crew members and piecing together the mysteries behind them, your murder, and the ship itself. I enjoyed possessing people and searching the ship, trying to find new info that would help move the narrative along, but if you're not into a lot of walking and talking that might get old quick. There are a lot of secrets in this game however, many of which are tied to the original flash game Why Am I Dead (which isn't necessary to play before this game), and I liked searching the ship for all of the achievements.
 
My only warnings about this game besides what I mentioned above would be some of the themes and potential glitches in this game. Despite it’s fairly harmless appearance, Why Am I Dead At Sea has heavy themes and language that might surprise you if you’re not prepared, so if that isn’t your cup of tea, consider yourself warned. I have also seen complaints of glitches around, but I never experienced any during my own playthrough.
 
If any of the above has piqued your interest, Why Am I Dead At Sea is definitely worth the price, especially if you buy it on sale. I believe a game with the thought, story, and soul of Why Am I Dead At Sea is easily worth 5 bucks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198144166098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1558819907}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062559906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1546135330}
review: Amazing game - great tense atmosphere, interesting characters, well paced plot development.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017163400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1495642357}
review: Earthbound being one of my favorite games of all time, the similarity of this game immediately struck me. However, whereas Earthbound is WholesomeMeme the game, Why Am I Dead at Sea is a dark murder mystery revealed through talking to about a dozen characters on the cruise ship. There is honestly not a lot of action in this game, it is entirely narrative. I have heard it described as a "Walk and talk" game which is pretty accurate. The game is not too long though and has multiple endings which cap off an engrossing mystery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083953039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1495394995}
review:
A very good crime solving story.

 The characters have touching/relatable backgrounds, or other personality traits that make them unlikeable; it gives depth to the characters and helps creating a climate of suspicion that doesn't give away the culprit from the get go. I would have hoped to get an ending that actually includes the main protagonist we play in the game, because they remain in the shadows. I can understand the creative choice to keep the mystery, but if it were me, I'd have liked it another way.

The gameplay is really simple and to the point, the special feature on each character is another advantage to get the story straight. 

My only issue would be with the saving option which doesn't let you save on one of the three slots during the game, you have to be in the Main menu and copy the file before making progress, and this is something I didn't do in my first 5 hours of playthrough, and I ended up stuck in the story and had to redo it all over again.

Regardless, there is a certain replayability in the game, hints and sentences you didn't quite understand during the first run and so on, it was well thought-out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078490068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1496079733}
review: A somewhat short but fun little mystery game. Although I think it really only has one playthrough in value (save before chapter 4, then try all the endings, which I intend to do) on sale at least, it's well worth the price point. There isn't really much to complain about here, sure a few of the tasks have somewhat contrived methods of completion, and others are mind numbingly simple, but that's just how it goes. As the characters go, even with the small amount of interaction, I found myself liking (or disliking) most of them. The mind reading mechanic, for example, while it doesn't offer any benefit, offers a really cool look into their heads with the different backgrounds. Overall, it's a pretty solid little game, just remember to save constantly, as it gives no warning when exiting. Then again maybe I've been spoiled by autosave.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007747398', 'num_games_owned': 937, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1495188585}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053193833', 'num_games_owned': 1362, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1495115148}

author: {'steamid': '76561198036943999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1495221881}
review:
I buy alot of cheap games here on steam. Most of the time they've got little good pieces but are overall pretty bad. But every now and again, I find a real gem hidden in all that dross, and this was one of them. Low production value, a number of minor non-gamebreaking bugs, but superb mystery and characters. Honestly, I found that this game captured all the things I liked about the Nonary Games (albeit in a different format and without escape sequences.)

The game takes the form of an overhead RPGmaker style game (without combat), like corpse-party or mad-father. You play as a ghost who can possess characters to some degree and read minds, but not work outside the context of that character's norm. A few characters have special abilities (technically they all do, but most of them are abilities like 'i change the background music' or 'I made amusing and silly flavor-text announcements over the PA' or 'I take a pill to walk faster'). So that means most of the game is instigating conversations between different people, although there are a few "figure out how to get the key" moments. In any case, swapping characters is a great mechanism for allowing you to investigate the story from different angles. As you get to know certain characters better, you get higher degrees of control over them, and so in some situations you need to learn more about each character to advance the plot. 

There is a hint system as well, although it was disabled at the end of the game when I really needed it. It offers both vague suggestions that give you a rough idea of where to look, but you can press for more specific ones. I did the specific one once, and the result was almost as explicit as a walkthrough "try taking this character and talking to this other character to open up more dialog options, then return with a different character and they'll react differently." I liked that because it ensured you never got really stuck, but again, it is disabled at the end and I ended up getting stuck once, although I did feel like the specific ones were a bit too easy.

This game is a murder mystery, and an excellent one at that. Multiple people are working in different directions, without knowing the entire story. Everyone has their secrets, and almost noone is who they initially appear to be. It creates a complex and intricate situation to unravel. The game does an excellent job of dropping just the right hints and the right pieces to keep things interesting without giving away too much. 

The ending takes place with a big confrontation between all the characters, a little like you'd expect from an Agatha Christie novel. Except instead of a detective putting together all the pieces of the mystery, that role falls to the player. So you take control of each character to get them to reveal their piece of the puzzle, and try to reveal the whole mystery. I'll admit, I missed a few pieces the first time, so the game ended with parts of the mystery unsolved. I'm not sure how many endings there are, but apparently there's more than one. I need to go through a second time to see if I can figure out the rest of it. 

The character development is one of the best things about this game. There are numerous characters, all with their own backstory and motives. Some are innocent. Some, not so much. Everyone's hiding something though, and as you sort through the evidence you come to understand the characters and get attached to them in their own way. Their interactions are complex and dynamic. Manipulative and dishonest at times as well (at least if I didn't misinterpret any pieces of the mystery)

There are lots of problems with the game too. The character sprites are good, but everything else is kind of bland. The music is simplistic and obnoxious, and I ended up turning off the sound about a half hour after I started the game each time. The characters were said to each have special abilities, but I'd say maybe half at least of them were useless. Also, the story can get caught at times, and your only way to continue is cycle through each of the characters and they've all talked to each other and exhausted all dialog options, which is a pain. The scenery never changes either. There's maybe two dozen rooms, most of which are tiny, and they get kinda old by the end. 

Also there are alot of bugs... nothing game-breaking, but just annoyance kind of stuff. The biggest one I saw was when you tried to enter a room, but another character was blocking the door in the other room. You'd enter and get pushed back out, or end up inside a wall. Also, sometimes you'd click on a door and it wouldn't react at all. Normally you'd get a "door's locked" or "I shouldn't go in" message, but sometimes you got nothing. There was an ability for the ghost to scan who he could control, and it lagged horribly whenever I used it. Also the game wanted to restart every time I exited it, so I could only close it by rapidly jamming alt-f4. Nothing gamebreaking, but obnoxious. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this game. If you like mysteries with strong characters anyway. It's got alot of little bad things, but the overall game is so great. The game took me about 7 hours on my first playthough, although may have left it idling a few times while I got dinner ready, and I'm not sure how much that inflated it. Still, it's much more length than I usually get out of a cheap game like this. The characters and mystery were masterfully executed.

I will certainly keep an eye on this developer. If they can produce more stories with such great characters and plotlines, especially if they can add a little more polish, we might be looking at some real masterpieces in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069852998', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1494928066}
review:
I love this game. The name, honestly is pretty dull and the art is barebones but what makes up for all of this is an excellent murder mystery wrapped up in flawed and interesting characters.

One of my favorite choices design-wise is a character named Paulo. He's completely isolated from all the action and therefore I never felt pressure when talking to him. Paulo gives a little backstory but what I especially loved what that he exists as essentially an in-game walkthrough. Paulo will rarely give straight answers, but he will point you to what characters/ areas of the game you need to focus on to complete the story. He's a great crutch for players (like me), who frequently struggle to solve these types of games but he doesn't take the fun out of solving the mystery. He does what Contradiction's chief tried to do, but he fills his role much better because of how we are introduced to Lewis. Such a simple character that gives the player a lot of leeway in how they want to approach the game!

Another thing i liked: i got the feeling the game had a lot of respect for the player. There's a point in chapter two where one of the main riddles of the game could have been solved with context clues in the dialog, but the answer is never spoken out loud until chapter three. However, at the end of chapter two the game gives dialog options to the player as if the mystery had already been revealed. This showed me the game had faith that the player was working the mystery on their own and didn't need obvious plot points to be outlined to them.

Noteworthy: The game gets dark, but it's not really edgy like a lot of games are now. This is a personal thing, but I hate games that try to be edgy, pushing things sexual harassment and gruesome murders in the gameplay and forcing the player to watch. Not that the game strays from those topics, but i appreciated the tact shown when handling sensitive subjects. 

There are a ton of choices in the game, but never does the player have an actual impact on the story. While you can approach the story in a nonlinear fashion by following different leads and characters, the narrative is ultimately linear and events happen in a fixed sequence. I appreciate this, because it meant for things like dialog are almost always repeatable. This is a very pleasant change for someone whose always worried about missing an option, even if it's a little disorientating when you give conflicting answers to one question.

Now with all that said, I did have several issues (mostly technical) that would have made me quit the average title. These include:
-having to completely restart my game because the first mate got stuck inside an invisible wall. Easily the biggest issue
-Almost all the controls for gameplay are with keyboard, but in the audio menu you can only escape using the mouse?
-the name, while descriptive, is pretty dull. If it wasn't on sale I’d never look into this game.
-unskippable cutscenes
-there is no auto-eject out of conversations. Honestly this one is super nitpicky, but i hate accidently starting conversations and having to mash through 4 textboxes
+-to that point there is also no button to progress a conversation other than 'k,' or whatever you remap it to. This means if you mash 'k' too fast you can accidently conversation you might accidently start it again. Having another button to progress the conversation that doesn't start a new one would be nice.
-sometimes crewmen back block doors. I see no reason why collision with other passengers is needed, especially with this sort of drawback
-The ending feels really messy. SPOILERS: The best ending comes out in a clever and logical way, but it's attachment to 4 other endings makes it an extremely painful trial and error bonanza (if you don't give up and grab the walkthrough like i did). Moreover, the entire game is designed so that you can also go back and redo events, and nothing you can do is permanent. Having major elements of the story locked away behind optional activities at the very end feels cheap as hell, mostly because it only happens once in the entire game. Considering the games linearity up the that point, it might have made more sense to have only one or two endings. 

All that icky stuff aside, love the game and will definitely be looking for other stuff the dev has made :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198349195327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1494799252}
review: What an amazing game. The music is great and I love how every character has a track that describes them. The graphics are really good as well, but the real masterpiece here is the plot. It's a well written game that draws you into its story and makes you forget how long you've been playing for. I like the mechanics of how you gain partial and full control of characters and how you need to be thorough in interrogating them all to uncover pieces of the truth. Don't know what else to say, it's just a really charming game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025823574', 'num_games_owned': 3339, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1494582856}
review:
A superb murder-mystery when you're playing the ghost of a deceased, who tries to solve the of the circumstamces of their death. You do this by posessing the passangers and crewmembers, lightly setting them into the good direction but they are making their reactions based on their personality.  It sounds cliché, but everyone hides something, be it a huge, dark secret, a tragic backstory or just a side of their personality they don't like to face. 
The game operates wonderfully - for example the first creature you can posess is a cat, and every single person's reaction is reflecting their personality, as they react to the cat. Each person has a theme music that fits their personality. You'll have access later to a feature that visualize their personality, and that's also incredibly aligned with their reactions, personality and music, or even with just the walking speed of theirs. (The music is outstandingly great, by the way. Just look up Fingerless Gloves or yoloswag420blazeit as an OST, these were my favourites. Just care for spoilers in comments)
I think the game did a great job at presenting personalities, how different views would collide, while gradually uncovering a really well done plot that was unfolding in a small ship, between a handful, but well-developer characters. The graphics are kind of... lacking, as some item's design and the gorgeous sky is anything worthwhile to mention (most of the story is on a simple ship) but the story, the narrative and how the whole story is being delivered makes this an outstanding game at it's price range, not to even mention sales!

author: {'steamid': '76561198253931998', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1458890951}
review: Can Someone say: good ass story?   honestly a good fun experience, where you have to go around, collecting evidence on a murder, *as the victim*. you possess people, look into their minds, and honestly i was amazed that in order to see all the endings, you didn't just have to collect all the evidence, you had to piece it all together correctly in one big final moment! It's Awesome!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064221865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1492915141}
review: I loved this game. It was suspenseful, it contained a number of interesting, well fleshed out characters and it utilized some really awesome mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169065267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1492642714}
review:
A great game with intruiging characters and an engaging story, not to mention fun gameplay.
No character is like he seems on the surface and the story will keep you on your toes, all while listening to
some great music and  basking in the earthbound-esque graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055946235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1489714877}
review:
Why Did I Shit My Pants
There are no satisfying endings in this game. I had a lot of fun but it was super disappointing. Great premise, good level of creepiness and mystery, but terrible wrap-up. Not a single ending felt rewarding. Some questions were left unanswered and others would have been better off that way. Real weak follow-through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035916873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1511647569}
review:
This game is absolutely worth your time if you like ghosts, murder mysteries, or story-driven games, and it's a steal even at the regular price. It's a bit on the shorter side, but the multiple endings, engrossing story, and rich details make it worth at least one replay. 

This isn't the only game where you play a murder victim back from the dead (with Ghost Trick being another great example), but Why Am I Dead At Sea executes the concept masterfully. The mechanics change as the player gains a better understanding of their former identity and the people around them, tying together narrative and gameplay in a way that feels satisfying and natural. All the characters have multiple layers, and their interactions are realistic and well-written. Also, I loved the way the human mind was handled. Reading someone's mind displays some abstract visuals that give you a glimpse of their general attitude, with snippets of text floating by as their surface thoughts. It's not a huge deal, but it does a great job of making the mind feel dynamic and real. Much more creative than just having a line or two of inner monologue. Also, interaction between characters is well-written and engaging, even in cutscenes when the player isn't at the wheel. For the most part, the things a posessed character is willing to say will tell you as much as the answer you get in return. Also, even within the same ending, characters will act a bit differently depending on what you made them say earlier in the game. Otherwise, the story is mostly linear before a certain point, although some things don't need to be done in a certain order. This gives the player a nice sense of flexibility.

There were a couple of issues I had, though. First of all, the last stretch of the game is a bit difficult to navigate. The pacing of the story doesn't suffer much, but there's a relative lack of guidance and some of the things you need to do are accomplished in an unintuitive way. Throughout the game, it can be difficult to figure out what to do, but this issue becomes more pronounced as the game goes on. A more astute player might have less trouble juggling all the information they have, but sometimes it's hard to tell which character needs to talk to who, especially near the end. Also, while the endings are mostly satisfying, I felt like a couple of characters could use a little more focus, or at least acknowledgement. Those issues, in my opinion, are still far outweighed by the strength of the characters and the excitement of unraveling the story.

In conclusion, Why Am I Dead At Sea is a thrilling experience, packed to the brim with complex characters and unique mechanics. An excellent mystery and a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052182092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1489459185}
review: I was completely enthralled by this game and had to play it through in only two sittings. The visuals are reminiscent of later NES games and are so charming that the staging of the finale hits with shocking gravitas. The gameplay is not a unique concept, but it's one that is still fresh enough to feel new and engaging. Being able to possess characters with different skills to solve puzzles was immensly satisfying, and just challenging enough to avoid boredom or frustration. I highly recommend Why Am I Dead At Sea!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051715743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1489574928}
review:
An awesome adventure.
Pros:
A clever detective story, with a bit of Agatha Christie feel to it, where you try to solve a crime and find a murderer.
Very nice characters, cool game mechanics.
Nicely drawn, and with good music.
Also there are hints that make it hard to get really stuck.
Cons:
A couple of small bugs here and there (found 1 mechanical and a couple in the dialogue)
Leaves you with a taste for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053623100', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1491648817}
review:
The general concept of the game is already well presented, so let's just skip to the pros and cons:

Pros: 
- The characters are memorable.  They vary in depth, but most of them have multiple levels that make them interesting to discover.
- The story is above average.  There is a nice sense of progression -- although the fact that it will have twists is obvious, what those twists are isn't always.  

Neutral:
- The majority of the game is the conversational aspect.  There are very few puzzles, and what puzzles there are are pretty simple.

Cons:
- A game-breaking bug where characters can get stuck in place and unable to move, requiring you to edit the save file to continue.   You're advised to keep multiple saves.
- The plot runs on a script, regardless of your choices.  If you figure something out before you're supposed to, you can't do anything about it until the plot catches up.  Towards the end, you may know exactly what you need to do, but get stymied because you can't figure out the series of actions the game is expecting to advance the plot.
- The game begins to fall apart, mechanically, towards the end.  Actions that were able to be done earlier in the game cannot be repeated even though there's been no change, some actions (like attempting to open a locked door) no longer give any feedback at all, etc.
- Sometimes keystrokes are dropped, especially during conversations.  This is doubly annoying because you don't want to accidentally overpress the key either, or you'll inadvertently skip things.

All in all, I enjoyed the first 75% or so of the game, but the last quarter just got downright frustrating, which unfortunately left a bad aftertaste.  Still, I got several hours of enjoyment out of it, making it worth the $5 going price, much less the the $2 I actually paid for it, so it still ends up with a positive rating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069282877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1490059767}
review:
-Interesting characters and story
-Good music
-Fun puzzle-like gameplay (like figuring out who to possess/who to talk to in order to progress the story)
-You get to play as a cat at some points :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198298176243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1489996833}
review: Great game, with interesting characters and storyline. I'd love to see more like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018539708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1499, 'last_played': 1489917329}
review:
Video games occuring behind closed doors are rare, and this one does it perfectly.
Unraveling the story behind each protagonist is satisfying, the plot is very well-written, and it avoids the usual pitfalls: it's not obvious, it does not need to be overly complicated to maintain the suspense, and above all, there is no deus ex machina, everything makes sense at the end.

A very unusual and pleasant game, well worth the price for anyone looking for a good story.

Obviously not for gamers looking for action, though, this game is all about talking to people.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989846361', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 854, 'last_played': 1489852897}
review:
I originally looked at the screenshots, and I was skeptical. However, the reviews convinced me to buy this at the low price of $1.99, and boy was it worth it. The game worth it at $4.99 too.

This game is original, and the characters are fleshed out and realistic. The trading cards sell for a decent amount (about $0.20 each). 

The twist is great, and the story is interesting. The dialogue is unique, and your choices matter.

I would highly recommend it.

I am now going to play the first game, "Why am I dead: Rebirth" because that is how much I loved this. That game is free!

Yes, there are glitches, but they are minor; if you save often, they will not be a problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028340642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1489877699}
review:
I really really like this game.

I've had my eye on this game for months waiting for it to go on sale, it did and I bought it. However, I wish i'd just taken the plunge and paid full price. If this game looks like it would interest you and you're on the fence about buying it, take my advice and ADD TO CART.

WAIDAS blends a quirky humour with a sinister story. If you enjoyed games such as Mother 1-3 or Phoenix Wright ace attorney, I think you'll like this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069872930', 'num_games_owned': 612, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1489813529}
review: very interesting and enjoyable

author: {'steamid': '76561198068553752', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1489578158}
review: Fun murder mystery game. It's well put together and all of the characters are really fleshed out and realistic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311859475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 858, 'last_played': 1630823623}
review:
Criminally underrated. All the characters are extremely detailed and fleshed out; sometimes a simple optional observation can give entire new depth to the story that wouldn't be known otherwise. And that's all I can say without spoiling anything. It really seems that as far as story goes, this game is pretty impeccable.

As far as negatives go, there are some minor gameplay gripes. Players constantly going back to specific places when you're done possessing them, as well as certain characters walking really slowly, can get a little annoying, but it's in service to the plot and character development, and that is the main focus of the game, anyway. 

There's also the complaint that the gameplay really boils down to talking to random people as random people, but I'd beg to differ. I can't speak for everyone (and obviously I don't), but in my personal playthrough, I very rarely felt like I was just randomly guessing at what to do. Very few games provide, and reward players for following, clues as successfully as this game, and if you feel like you're fresh out of leads, you can always talk to Paulo. The few times I did come to a conclusion through random guessing, my reaction was kinda, "Oh, I should've figured," as the clues are always there. Except, that is, in the Fourth Chapter. THAT is the point where I think this criticism is valid, as the game hits a bit of a lul, not only because of the absence of Paulo, but also because it takes a long time before a visual change in the ship, which kinda makes you wonder when a major change in the story is gonna come, as well as making the gameplay feel a little monotonous. Without spoiling too much, though, this lul doesn't last for long.


Overall, if I had to sum up this game in a number, I'd give it like an 8/10 (Really goooooood maaaaaaaan)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049617320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1489522038}
review:
i couldn't put it down. every character had a depth that impressed the hell out of me. brilliant design, engrossing mystery, crazy twists. it kept me guessing until the end! 

super super recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128748983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1488241320}
review: Those are the most believable and compelling characters I've seen in quite a while. Awesome gameplay, very interesting mechanics. "Why am I Dead at Sea" is an inspiration for game developers everywhere in the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166307768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1654554051}
review: I love it. Earthbound style art was one of the many reasons why this game won me over.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006986577', 'num_games_owned': 684, 'num_reviews': 467, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1486391183}
review: Imagine the team behind Earthbound went on to make a mystery adventure game.  The developer draws clear influence from Earthbound(my favorite game) but really makes it his own.  The art and music are wonderful, and the story(with multiple endings) is just fantastic!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051698205', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1486357978}

author: {'steamid': '76561198085709896', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1576562920}

author: {'steamid': '76561198139708217', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1484660213}
review: THIS GAME IS A FUCKING MASTERPIECE

author: {'steamid': '76561198057147585', 'num_games_owned': 732, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1484528511}
review:
I have just played through the entire thing in one sitting.
Great example of a story that needs to be a game. It's hard to imagine it in any other format.
The premise alone is a good one; a standard murder mystery based on conversation matchups, all depending on who will (accidentally?) reveal information to who.

Plot is suitably complex, beautifully written characters, fantastic execution of music, soundtrack itself is incredible -
It's hard to go wrong here. Fully recommend.

+ you actually need to work out what happened, rather than let the game do it for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018055499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1484461495}
review: I guess I was only expecting this to be a lite little mystery adventure, so I was surprised with just how engaged I became with it. Sure there's only half a dozen locations, but some unique point'n'click gameplay mechanics (2 different levels of character possession, individualised character abilities) kept the proceedings feeling fresh and fun. The plot was more developed and characters way deeper than I was expecting. The dialogue style rolled out like retro Japanese RPGs/Adventures—similar to 'To the Moon'. And the music was way better than I was expecting. My low expectations must've stemmed from the visuals which, even for a retro lo-res pixel style, are on the drab side—but this didn't turn out to be a hindrance to overall enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996656102', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 335, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1483696936}
review:
Przygodówka kryminalna, w której jako duch zamordowanego kapitana statku rozwiązujesz zagadkę własnej śmierci poprzez przejmowanie kontroli nad kolejnymi pasażerami. W takiej postaci szukasz poszlak, rozmawiasz z ludźmi, starasz się ich poznać i wywnioskować, kto z nich był zabójcą.

To cwana produkcja, w którą włożono sporo wysiłku. Gdy rozmawiasz z ludźmi pod różnymi postaciami, te dialogi są inne. Każdemu mówią co innego. Każdy też jest interesujący i skrywa jakieś klasyczne drugie dno swoich motywacji. Z czasem dowiadujemy się, co tak naprawdę dzieje się na statku. I chcemy wiedzieć więcej.

Na plus zaliczam też zakończenia w liczbie mnogiej, gdzie na podstawie dowodów sam musisz doprowdzić do rozwiązania. Możesz doprowadzić nawet do tego, że winny nie zostanie odkryty, albo ktoś niewinny zgarnie winę na siebie.

Dobra produkcja. Dobrze spędzone 2€. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993406809', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1483419905}
review: Pretty fun! In Why Am I Dead At Sea, you play as a ghost trying to learn who you are and why you were murdered. You do this by possessing the bodies of other characters on a boat, all potential suspects, to help unravel the mystery. The writing is flawed at times but generally pretty interesting. It does an especially nice job ramping up as you progress in the adventure, and I couldn't help but see it through in one sitting. I think anyone interested in story-driven games should check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154261897', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1701804164}
review:
One of the most underrated games I have ever played. Definitely a buy for this price.

Pros:
+Great soundtrack
+Memorable Characters
+Smooth gameplay
+possessing people is awesome
+Multiple endings make your story unique
+You have to use your head, each ending depends on your total evidence and if you have examined everything
+The endings do deliver (Its not an "It was Cthulu all along" type of thing at all)

Cons:
-Rare Minor Graphical glitches

Tips ( Spoilers )
+ [spoiler] Not all the abilities for each character are manditory in completing a storyline [/spoiler]
+ [spoiler] Talk to everyone about everything [/spoiler]

Overall an AMAZING game

author: {'steamid': '76561198103916275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 274, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1483468045}
review:
Spannung von Anfang bis Ende

Why Am I Dead At Sea konnte mich von Anfang bis Ende fesseln, und das obwohl die zahlreichen Probleme im Bereich Steuerung fleißig versucht haben mir den Spaß zu verderben. Miese Vorkonfiguration der Tastenbelegung, kein Controller-Support, mangelhafte Kollisionsabfrage zwischen einigen Spielfiguren und Umgebungsobjekten … Das hätte alles nicht sein müssen. Doch die packende Handlung rund um menschliche Seelenqualen und Abgründe zwingt einen förmlich dazu weiterzuspielen und wenigstens ein paar der insgesamt vier Endings freizuspielen. Unterstützt wird man dafür von einem tollen, abwechslungsreichen Soundtrack und netter Retro-Grafik im Earthbound-Stil. Außerdem ist es einfach ein cooles Konzept als Geist von Menschen Besitz zu ergreifen, um auf diese Weise einen verzwickten Fall zu lösen.;)


Pro und Kontra:

Pro:
- spannendes, wenn auch nicht wirklich neues Grundkonzept (ein Geist als Detektiv)
- packendes Mystery-Krimi-Drama mit erwachsenen Themen
- abwechslungsreiche Charaktere mit Geheimnissen und Tiefgang
- toller Soundtrack
- bietet mehrere Auflösungsstufen
- gewohnt simple Steuerung, aber …

Neutral:
- charmante Grafik im Stil des JRPG-Klassikers Earthbound, passt jedoch nicht unbedingt gut zur düsteren Handlung
- solide Spielzeit von ca. 6 Stunden (ist für 4,99 € in Ordnung)
- ist kein klassisches Adventure, das Spiel besteht fast ausschließlich auf Dialogführung

Kontra:
- … die Steuerung ist schlecht vorkonfiguriert und bietet keinen Controller-Support
- einige Spielfiguren verhaken immer wieder mal mit Umgebungsobjekten
- die vollständige Übernahme eines Wirts ist unnötig kompliziert und umständlich


Das vollständige Review: http://www.gamecontrast.de/why-am-i-dead-at-sea-review/#more-61159

author: {'steamid': '76561198027343237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1483460473}
review:
All things considered, this is a good story. I say "story" rather than "game" because I think there's this notion going around that a video game has to have gameplay. This doesn't. You interact with the world and the characters through a set of mechanics, but it's more a storytelling device than a game.

There were things I didn't like. The supernatural angle didn't end up being particularly relevant. It only provided a way within the context of the story for the player to interact with the world. I'd have like to see it taken further. There are a couple of optional scenes in which the player character uses their ghostly powers to help a character conquer their personal demons from within. I wanted to see more of that, but then the game ended.

If you've played Capcom's [i]Ghost Trick[/i] - and you should - I'd compare this game to it as shorter, less interesting, with a less satisfying ending. But it is more grounded, which can be seen as a good thing, depending on whether you think the supernatural element clashes or not.

All that said, if you ever have an urge for a murder mystery thriller story with a supernatural framing device, this game is what you're looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148661644', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1483389485}
review:
Do not sleep on this gem.  I repeat, do not sleep on it. Why Am I Dead At Sea is an underrated gem that you need to experience. From the graphics, maybe it shares similarities with Earthbound. But, it's different from gameplay aspects. If you like Undertale, i think you'll like this one.

I thank Steam Community for the recommendation. For a low low price, what could possibly go wrong? Approximately 6 hours for one playthrough, and did i mention this game has multiple endings? No? Ok, now you know.

Nice graphics, amazing mechanics (I must admit, its very unique.), great characters personalities and interactions, and a well written mystery game. Peltast Software, please make another game, i will surely buy it! To finish this review, discounted or not, you need to experience this unique gem.

The ultimate question is,
Why Am I Dead at Sea? or even better, Why Am I Still Reading the Reviews and Not Buying the Game Already?

10/10
(I absolutely love it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198024974513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1483322629}
review: Post-mortem murder mystery that looks like Earthbound and sounds like Homestuck. Touches on sexual abuse, human trafficking, suicide and class privilege in its tight run time. More 90s suspense than Agatha Christie in its inspiration, cruise ship location notwithstanding, but it's a meaty, provoking little gem with multiple endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015278081', 'num_games_owned': 2666, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482898714}
review:
Good murder mystery games are always such a thrill.

This game rides on a really nice and original concept that lets the player delve deep into each character's backstory and mind from everyone's perspective... literally.

10/10 Would try to figure out whodunnit again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025205047', 'num_games_owned': 1413, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482898433}
review:
This was a pretty fun mystery game. I enjoyed getting to know all the characters and using their abilities. There was one spot where I couldn't connect all the dots myself, but otherwise I feel like the game did a pretty good job of hinting me in the right direction. The endings were interesting, although sometimes a little corny in my opinion. Your miliage may vary. I bought this game on sale, but I feel like it's completely worth it at full asking price. 



If this developer makes another mystery game I'll probably buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193921170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482814099}
review:
Holy crap. Why didn't I buy this game sooner? I thought I'd be playing this game 4-5 hours max...I was wrong! 

You have died at sea, but your soul is not quite ready to move along to the afterlife. To find closure, you must use your newly found skills of possession and mind control to extract the truth from the ship's passengers. Don't be put off that this appears to be a Game Maker game, the story is absolutely riveting and the writing is excellent. The mechanics are well implemented and it's a lot of fun being able to see what individuals on the ship are thinking. I spent 12 hours on my first playthrough, and I am sure I will be back for more to achieve the alternate endings.

10/10 Highly recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198147733367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1482696043}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040695367', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1482110249}
review: I really enjoyed this game much more than I thought I would. I expected a kind of gamey whodunit mystery, but it very quickly turned into an enthralling story of interesting characters and a surprising amount of suspense for such a simple looking game. My only real complaint is that in the final act, when loose ends are meant to come together in a build-up to the climax, the pacing almost drops dead with some of the puzzle solving and how contrived it has become in order to address all points, but it manages to recover well in the final scenes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220519669', 'num_games_owned': 3214, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1480547646}
review: I enjoy a good mystery, and I thought the visuals were neat, so I expected to have a fun time playing this game.  What I did not expect, though, was just how interesting the cast of characters could be, which was certainly helped by the gameplay mechanic of needing to learn about people to influence their actions.  The atmosphere in general was appealing, thanks in part to an excellent soundtrack.  And when it comes to length, while it was shorter than some mysteries, it was long enough to truly feel attached to the events occurring.  All in all, even if you don't consider yourself an amateur sleuth, I'd still suggest checking this game out.  Maybe you'll discover that you're a better detective than you'd thought by the end of it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048958356', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 465, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1711721729}
review:
While the premise (a ghost investigating their death by possessing others) has been done before in other games, [i]Why Am I Dead At Sea?[/i] shines in its characters and its intriguing plot. Most of the people you'll meet have depths hinted at in their uniquely-designed mental landscapes (with matching music) and their stories interact with each other and the main plot without any forced connections or co-incidences. The pacing is generally good and the art-style and music, while neither are particularly flashy, definitely complement and enhance the story and characters. About the only issue I would note is that sometimes it's easy to lose track of what your next objective is or who you've missed speaking to in order to progress the story, so you end up spending time wandering around in vain.

Overall, a definite recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079964843', 'num_games_owned': 5874, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 1623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1611, 'last_played': 1610389000}
review:
[quote]Верите ли вы в справедливость этого мира?[/quote]

Как думаете, сколько людей ежегодно умирают в море? Это покажется невероятным, но по исследованиям около 372.000 человек. "Вот это да", - скажете вы и представите в голове всех этих людей, тонущих одновременно. Не самая радужная смерть, конечно.
Так вот. В данной игре мы играем за призрака, в прошлом он был... кое-кем, кто тоже умер в море. Но вот как он умер? Утонул? Повесился у себя в каюте? Поскользнулся на верхней палубе и упал за борт прямиком в пасть акулы? Кто знает... Хотя, по первым мелькающим кадрам, становится понятно, что это[spoiler] убийство.[/spoiler]Вот и думай теперь, как ты умер, да почему. Вот таким недостатком информации игра потчует нас с самых первых минут. Мы играем за призрака, который находится на корабле. Ему необходимо расследовать причину своей смерти, а также попутно узнать информацию о себе и о прочих пассажирах корабля. Ведь не просто же так мы вернулись в этот мир.

Выглядит игра в изометрическом стиле, с очень уютной, прямо "по-домашнему" симпатичной пиксельной графикой. Да, это инди-проект, но любители ААА, не спешите с выводами. Музыка в принципе неплохая, пара-тройка треков даже может остаться у вас в голове, чтобы когда-нибудь вы вернулись к этой игре. В звуках нет ничего особенного. "Пиканье" в стиле 90-х для "озвучивания" речи и набор не самых выдающихся звуков (но это не значит, что они плохи). 

На корабле у нас числится 11 человек (включая нас), кошка и... а это уже найдите в самой игре. Очень хотелось бы написать о каждом более подробно, но это тот самый случай, когда интересно всё узнавать самому. Скажу только, что каждый персонаж яркий и колоритный, со своим характером, очень запоминающийся, со своими тайнами. У игрока нет ни капли информации и он черпает её по крупинке. Но, кое-что для разогрева интриги знать всё-таки нужно: призрак имеет определённые способности. Вселяться в людей, управлять ими, читать их мысли. Подобное было в громком проекте от Square Enix - Murdered: Soul Suspect. Но здесь это всё в целом выполнено НА ПОРЯДОК лучше, поверьте моему честному объективному слову. Правда, приходится чем-то жертвовать, и игра проходится буквально за 4-5 часов. Но это даже не минус! 

В целом, это инди-жемчужина, но, к сожалению, малоизвестная. Как видно по оценкам Steam, у неё исключительно положительные отзывы. Несколько отрицательных связаны с какой-то технической проблемой, а не историей игры. Но игра была обновлена после тех обзоров и теперь она ещё стабильнее. Осмелюсь сказать, что по крутости она может потягаться с самой To the moon, вот только Мэдисон её не обозревал. Только другого жанра, это следует учитывать, чтобы меня потом просто так не закидали тапочками. 

Кто знает, с чем вам предстоит столкнуться, пока вы идёте к истине, силясь понять почему вы умерли в море...

Русификатор доступен на http://www.zoneofgames.ru/forum/index.php?showtopic=42466 и теперь можно будет насладиться этой уютной инди с замечательным сюжетом, которая оставляет прекрасное послевкусие, на русском языке!
P.S. Есть антология на рутрекере (моя раздача). Там приквел к этой игре, который вышел раньше. Причём не просто приквел, а улучшенный приквел. Ну и переведённый на русский, конечно же. Помните - актуальная версия перевода на текущий момент 1.06. На некоторых сайтах есть старее - эта версия будет непроходима или с багами.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963366503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1502830024}
review:
[h1]Spoiler-free review[/h1]
I'm very critical when it comes to this type of indie game, but the writing in this one is actually very good. Perhaps most importantly for me, the dialogue writing feels fresh and interesting. The story keeps your curiosity piqued, and your brain working on figuring out the mystery. It's good stuff.

It gets off to a really good start that's almost immediately very engaging and dramatic (in no small part due to the soundtrack), and its characters feel surprisingly nuanced.

You get access to various unusual abilities that you can use while exploring or during conversations, and it meshes really well with the story (even if some are more useful than others. But I don't really see that as a flaw.)

Lots of things about this game work really well, but it does have a few pretty significant problems:

[b]Technical Issues[/b]
I've had to restart the game multiple times before I was able to finish it due to various technical problems, the most common of which is that some characters will get stuck before they reach their destination, and can never get unstuck.
Another odd issue i got was that the game's save files seemingly deleted themselves overnight.

[b]Design Flaws[/b]
It's very easy to get stuck not knowing what flag you haven't tripped so you can move on to the next thing. But the game dialogue is also oddly structured, which hurts the game's pacing.

Often, you seemingly need to "talk to everyone about everything", but the dialogue trees are oddly designed in that choices don't "stick". You can say every possible choice by just repeating a certain dialogue tree path.

If you haven't exhausted all your dialogue with a character, there's a "..." icon, but it doesn't go away before you've made every possible choice.
So the problem is the character you're controlling has to be a total weirdo who starts multiple identical conversations about the same topic by saying the exact same thing at first, and then ends it by, for example, stating wildly different opinions each time, say, 4 or 5 times, to the same character. This doesn't make sense in the narrative of the game, and stands out especially because the game is well written.

It seems to me that the game is signalling that exhausting all of these dialogue options and thus removing the "..." icon from every character is required to progress - but I'm honestly not sure how that really works. It's entirely unclear as you're playing, and becomes especially apparent if you (like me) end up playing the game multiple times.


[b]In conclusion[/b]
Skill and effort went into crafting this story, and I recommend this game to people who enjoy a good mystery.

If you can find a way to back-up your save files, then you might want to do that in case a character gets stuck, or the saves decide to disappear like mine. Or just beat it in one sitting.

I found it quite enjoyable despite having seen perhaps the worst of its flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055006994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1477145387}
review:
This reminds me of Ghost Trick, a lot, wich is good, and also of Murdered: Soul Suspect, a little. But where those games took the phantom premise to offer puzzles or stealth or wathever, this one on the other hand uses it only to offer a way to experience the story from each person´s perspective, making you possess different characters and uncover their backgrounds, and that awesome.

Recomended to any murder mystery fan out there or anyone else who is interested in the concept of a phantom detective.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049735451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1474935979}
review: I bought this game because the premise looked interesting--you get to be a ghost that possesses people in order to solve the crime of your own death.  What I didn't realize was that in the process of solving your own murder (or not solving it depending on the ending), you would get to learn the sad tales of all the other characters.  Almost everyone on the cruise had their faults and pains that haunted them, and nudging the characters here and there to find carthasis made the sappy soul inside of me so happy.  If you like story-centric games with minimal gameplay aside from swapping characters and investigating every nook and cranny, then I fully recommend you play this game.  For $5, I got 5 hrs of fun and would have had more had I not read a walkthrough for every instance I got stuck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096902741', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1516682300}

must own for any murder mystery fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025521262', 'num_games_owned': 600, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1473421177}
review:
[i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] is a murder mystery adventure game where you play a ghost with the ability to possess each of her potential murderers and lead them to find clues against one another in order to figure out whoddunit. A great concept, excellent execution, fun world design that rewards exploration with insight, just a wonderful and memorable gaming experience.

I am so into these games that offer unique modes of storytelling, I mean, it's a brilliant solution to a concept I've always hated in games: dead-eyed, slack-jawed NPCs who sit around waiting for you to do every little thing. You're ostensibly playing one entity, but really this game has more in common with "split the party" type horror games like [i]Siren[/i] or [i]Corpse Party[/i] where you play different people caught in the vortex of one event, each with their own fully realized personalities and desires. The care that has been put into constructing the characters is really what makes the game so great. Each character has unique music that plays when possessing them, a unique mindscape that can be peeked into, a unique placement in the societal incubator that is the setting, and each has different methods of talking to the other characters and dealing with the world they're situated in. In order to possess them, the game asks that you understand them, and thus witness them through the eyes of the people around them and then ultimately through their own. 

What results is a game that feels very empathic, very alive, where both the player and the characters seem to have so much agency towards pushing the story forward and solving the mystery. This ties into the existential crises of nearly all the characters, which range from poverty to surviving the suicide of a loved one to facing their own imminent deaths, the game offers several discussions on time and moving forward, overcoming traumas and spending whatever time you are given meaningfully and not just keeping your head down and doing the bare minimum to achieve comfort.

And the mystery is good! And more importantly, it's something you can figure out with the clues you're given even before you get to the final judgement, though how to organize those clues into evidence is harder than it initially seems.

Now, I did face a little bugginess, but nothing game ruining. Also I would have liked everyone to have different colored text boxes or something, it gets confusing in group scenarios. Otherwise... its-a goooood.
